front.head: TO Dr. JOHN SPEED of Southampton.

lg.l: TRUE Son of Heir t' his Tuneful Quill,
His murthering Arrows, and his healing Skill:
Thy Bills his Med'cines are, his Lyre thy Song,
Thine Heart his Quiver, and his Bow thy Tongue:
But here's no : Sooth thine Arms a while,
And charm thy stately Rigor to a Smile,
For no more; we love
well
Nor do we thus
may be
With Art, nor
A Lyrick Ode submits ;
no more offend
Nor nor nor Sacred
flows in tuneful
And feels the Pleasure, nor complains
Of Impositions, Prisons, Bonds, and Chains,
Whilst pure Devotion sings and th' Indul Reigns.
with Joy thine Iron Stile
To the soft Polish of a gentle File;
The Courteous Muse shines brightest; and 'tis fit
Heir should deal in kinder Wit.
to his Lute in Artful Numbers sings
Melodious; till his Angry Bow he brings
Across the Chorded Shell, and hurts the gentler Strings.
